headline: Chicago police chief rebukes 'Empire' star Jussie Smollett for lie, says bogus reports cause real harm

utterances.speaker: GREG GUTFELD, HOST
utterances.sentences: Hi, I'm Greg Gutfeld with Emily Compagno, Juan Williams, Jesse Watters, and she once rode horseback on a Chihuahua, Dana Perino. “The Five.”

utterances.speaker: EDDIE JOHNSON, CHICAGO P.D. SUPERINTENDENT
utterances.sentences: You know as a look out into the crowd, I just wish that the families of gun violence in this city got this much attention because that's who really deserves the amount of attention that we've given to this particular incident.  This morning, I come to you not only as the superintendent of the Chicago Police Department, but also as a black man who spent his entire life living in the city of Chicago. I know the racial divide that exists here. I know how hard it's been for our city and our nation to come together.  I also know the disparities and I know the history. This announcement today recognizes that Empire actor Jussie Smollett took advantage of the pain and anger of racism to promote his career. I'm left hanging my head and asking why. Why would anyone, especially an African-American man, use the symbolism of a noose to make false accusations? How could someone look at the hatred and suffering associated with that symbol and see an opportunity to manipulate that symbol to further his own public profile? Bogus police reports cause real harm. They do harm to every legitimate victim who's in need of support by police and investigators as well as the citizens of the city, and I'm also angry.  I love the city of Chicago and the Chicago Police Department, warts and all. But this publicity stunt was a scar that Chicago didn't earn and certainly didn't deserve. Smollett attempted to gain attention by sending a false letter that relied on racial homophobic and political language. When that didn't work, Smollett paid $3500 to stage this attack and drag Chicago's reputation through the mud in the process, and why? The stunt was orchestrated by Smollett because he was dissatisfied with his salary, so he concocted a story about being attacked. I only hope that the truth about what happened receives the same amount of attention that the hoax did.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: It's hard to top that, so I'm not even going to try. Jussie Smollett now faces a felony charge for filing a false report claiming that he was a victim, this after weeks of wasting the hard work of a dozen detectives, resources diverted from actual victims. So what's the lesson at CNN? All about lunch.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Sean Hannity is going to eat Jussie Smollett's lunch every single second. Tucker Carlson is going to eat Jussie Smollett's lunch every single second.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: The President of the United States --

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: The President of the United States is going to eat his lunch.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: What about “The Five?” We want to eat lunch, too. So that's Lemon's concern that the reaction to the crime is worse than the crime itself. Notice I'm not saying hoax. A hoax removes the media's complicity.   No, it was a crime aided and abetted by the activist press who embrace their perfect victim, ignoring all those implausible details. So, Don, no one is interested in eating Smollett's lunch but we'll eat yours and that of the whole consensus media who need a lesson in restraint and resisting its own activist confirmation bias. Lemon has made it no secret that he believes Trump supporters are racist, which is how Smollett portrayed them. So forget Smollett, he was just serving a function for the thirsty press seeking that story. Smollett, an attention addict with an anti-Trump fever, he read the room and saw that it was going to be easy to fool the media.  And he saw all of those sympathizing friends, like Don Lemon, as suckers. They should be pissed off at him. But he couldn't fool the cops or most of us. So if your only lesson is that Smollett will be used as father at this network while missing the fact that he played you then you're as hopeless as we thought. You should have been thrilled that the demand for hate crime exceeds the supply and that you don't means that it will probably happen again. Hey, Emily, you're a prosecutor. What are the legal ramifications of this entire case? Laid it out for us.

utterances.speaker: EMILY COMPAGNO, HOST
utterances.sentences: Well, for the filing a false police report he could face as we've heard up to three years in prison and then a huge fine.  And then for that letter, you know, there are consequences to the huge mechanism of responses that is put in place when you file a false police report and you allege a hate crime, or you send a letter with a threatening letter to a corporation building that then deploys a hazmat team, etcetera. So for that he could face up to ten years in prison. But I want to point out what I loved so much about the superintendent's comments --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Eddie Johnson, yeah.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.sentences: He brought it back to the real world, which is that there are real world consequences. And the hubris to me that emanates out of Hollywood where this celebrity will take something so painfully large such as the strife that has plague Chicago and this country in terms of its racial divide and historical consequences and symbolism of that news to shine for his own selfish gain because of a paycheck.   That, to me is -- I just loved that the speech by the superintendent because I felt like he brought it home to the real world. He said this isn't TV. This is what happens.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Juan, he did -- he said -- or they claim it was because he was dissatisfied with his paycheck. Do you believe that?

utterances.speaker: JUAN WILLIAMS, HOST
utterances.sentences: I don't know what to believe. I mean, that's what the chief said.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: The chief said -- what were your thoughts on what he said?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Oh, I like the chief, you know, I mean -- and I think he was very clear that he's -- and part of his disappointment was that as a black man in seeing Smollett take advantage of the racial tensions in American society. But, again, it's all about him. It wasn't about anybody else but him. I will say this, when the chief said he'd like to see more attention paid to things like the shooting in Chicago, what else, or especially to the -- as much attention to the initial charge as to the finding that this young man lied about it. The chief's wrong.   All the analysis shows that there's more attention now to the idea that he lied because it's a conspiracy issue. It's a fraud issue. It's celebrity gossip. There is more -- and don't forget, Donald Trump. Donald Trump has jumped in and said, you know, he was wrong, and it fits in with Donald Trump's attacks on the media, so all the Trump crowd is celebrating this in a way that I --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: No, they're just -- they're vindicated.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: No, they're not --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: They're vindicated.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Who said there was any need for them --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: They were accused. They were the symbolic accused.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: No, he said they put a red hat on one, but that wasn't the heart of the charge. And the letter was that he was the victim of some kind of racial crime. And again, there're so many racial crimes, we've seen a spike of racial crimes in the country --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: -- and he --this guy Smollett is so narcissistic that he is out of touch with reality. And the chief -- the chief should know more media attention, more cameras at that police department today than ever before.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Well, we can talk until the end of time about your misinterpretation of the facts. Let's go to GMA and get Smollett's own words before I get to Jesse.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Why do you think you were targeted?

utterances.speaker: JUSSIE SMOLLETT, ACTOR
utterances.sentences: I can just assume, I mean, I come really, really hard against 45. I come really, really hard against his administration. And I don't hold my tongue. If I had said it was a Muslim or Mexican or someone black, I feel like the doubters would have supported me a lot much more.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: So, Jesse, when I listen to him, I see somebody who knew how to play the media because the media could be -- that's the language that the media understood if you're an activist media.

utterances.speaker: JESSE WATTERS, HOST
utterances.sentences: All right, he framed 60 million Trump supporters and the media bought it hook line and sinker. Juan, I think what the chief was saying also is that he'd like to see that much media attention when there's a shooting, or black on black violence, or gang activity in the south side of Chicago too. Now, Smollett makes reportedly from 400,000 to $1.1 million a year.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Sixty grand an episode, I believe.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: He does not have any children, which means he's filthy rich. So, instead of trying to earn more money working hard, he perpetrated this hoax. And everything he accused Donald Trump of, he himself is guilty of. He is a liar. He is corrupt. And he is greedy.   So, just let that sink in also. Real hate crimes now are going to be treated with more skepticism, unfortunately, and that's what the police chief said, and I think that's probably one of the biggest results of this. Also, how dumb does Robin Roberts look right now when she went out there, didn't ask him any follow-up questions and let him perform like that? I bet she wish she had that back. Also, think about all the framed jobs and the conspiracy theories which we've seen. All it takes is a little common sense. You talked about it yesterday. There's a bunch of MAGA guys in a polar vortex in Chicago hate criming people. OK. Kavanaugh in high school, was he really participating in drug-fueled orgies? Or Covington, let's see -- wait a second, a 16-year-old, 115-pound kid was confronting some adult like the Ku Klux Klan? And now, Donald Trump, it makes you suspicious of the entire Russia investigation.   He -- Donald Trump is a Russian asset? Donald Trump is a Russian asset? You don't have any sort of doubt when someone says that? If you don't believe that there is any sort of suspicion when someone says Trump is a Russian asset, you're crazy and you're going to fall for another one of these hoaxes.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: What about the U.S. landing on the moon? I think that calls -- this calls it into question.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Dana?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Oh, my gosh.

utterances.speaker: DANA PERINO, HOST
utterances.sentences: Well, a couple of things, one, so he makes $65,000 an episode. His bail was just set at $100,000. So he's going to post bail with a week and a half worth of work. I wonder how like the AOC's of the world feel about this filthy rich person being able to walk away free because -- you know, right, we need bail reform.  The other thing though, I really like what Matt Lewis had to write today. I would cite him because I couldn't say it better. He writes for The Daily Beast. He said that the desire for sympathy and the moral authority that comes from being victimized has replaced the desire for admiration or respect for some act of heroism.  So it's like victim chic. If you are a victim, then you're going to get more attention and he knew that. But I do think it's kind of bizarre though. To your point, he was able to fool some at the media, not all.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Remember, there were people on the left who are frustrated, like GQ Magazine wrote about the reporter in this case saying how dare they use the word, allegedly.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: That that was whitewashing the idea that this was a hate crime when reporters were just actually doing their job.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: By the way, Jesse, I think with the Robin Roberts thing, we use the tape of the interview. I think that is an indication that she actually got this guy to say what he wanted to say. And for him, that's part of the indictment of him.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: That's true. He set himself up.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: That's what I'm saying So I don't think that's the reporter.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Well, I would have asked a few more follow-ups, that's all I'm saying. No offense to Robin --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: You would have quiz her on geography and -- anyway. All right, much more on Smollett -- Smollett, ahead. But first, major hypocrisy from 2020 Dems pushing socialist agendas, details next. Peter Tork.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Welcome back, 2020 Democratic contenders are being accused of hypocrisy for publicly slamming the rich while privately rolling in the dough. Watch this.

utterances.speaker: SEN. BERNIE SANDERS, I-VT
utterances.sentences: We should not have a grotesque level of wealth inequality in which three billionaires now own more wealth than the bottom half of the country.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: We have a tax bill that got past that gave a trillion dollars to the top 1 percent and the biggest corporations of America. And they need to give that money back.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: I want these billionaires to stop being freeloaders. I want them to pick up their fair share.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Some are calling foul on those candidates for these reasons. First, Bernie Sanders owned three houses and has earned over a million bucks in recent years. Kamala Harris reportedly held a fund-raiser in Beverly Hills attended by wealthy Hollywood and TV executives. And Elizabeth Warren's net worth is reportedly more than $8 million putting her in the top 1 percent, indeed. On -- one of the staffers twitter profiles for Congresswoman Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez, it says every -- for every billionaire is a policy mistake. Jesse, so now it's gone from trying to help bring the bottom up by, like, incentives or education, but now it's just completely top-down.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: I wonder if she thinks George Soros is a mistake. Tell that to his face, AOC. I don't think they're even that rich anyway. I mean, $1 million, I mean, compared to Donald Trump or some of these other people, that's nothing. Remember what Trump said about --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: That's their point.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: What Trump said about Mitt Romney. He's poor.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: And he walks like a penguin. When I see a wealthy person with a yacht, I don't get jealous. I get competitive and I want to own my own yacht. I want to work for my yacht. And I don't want to take that yacht away from someone else. I want to get it myself. And I think that's what the Democrats are kind of off. They see wealthy people and they want to make them less wealthy. I think they should be looking at poor people and say how do you make poor people less poor? Look what Barack Obama did. Barack Obama raised taxes on the rich. Middle-class wages didn't grow. The deficit didn't get paid down. Manufacturing jobs weren't created and the poverty rate stayed the same. So I don't see a big economic success when you raised taxes on the rich. I think they just waste the money on pork and corruption.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: When you are -- in Seattle. You live in Seattle. And so, there's a lot of tension between, sort of, more the local folks there that are mad about the tech companies and the billionaires and it's created a lot of tension there. And wasn't it just recently that they tried to raise taxes and then they had to backtrack because businesses were going to leave?

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.sentences: It was a huge deal. And then, Amazon donated $500 million to combat homelessness. So there's also a dependency on the private funding that happens in addition to what it does for the industry there, absolutely.  I think my biggest issue with all of this is the hypocrisy knows no bounds for these politicians. Like for example, you know, Elizabeth Warren, you know, she has -- she's millions in her funds and that include -- those funds include gun manufacturers and big tobacco and all of the things that she rails against. And it's that same hypocrisy that we hear up and down where people -- you know, walk the walk. Don't just talk the talk. We have Bernie Sanders, the day that his campaign paid $300,000 in jet airplane costs for his campaign, he tweeted out that climate change was a planetary crisis. So it's --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: I see, yeah.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.sentences: -- it's everything.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: There is -- a coin a phrase, selective billionaire outrage.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: SBO.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: SBO. They like --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: SBO.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: They don't like billionaires.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: He's got SBO, which stinks.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: We'll be right back.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: What do you think of that, SBO?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: You can treat it with super beats.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Because they have like Tom Steyer.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yeah, you know -- OK, OK. So I'm -- Bernie has three houses which prove a point that you can be a successful socialist if you act like a capitalist. That's the only way it's going to work. I'm not going to bash these -- any of these people for being wealthy because I think it's great that they're wealthy. I think everybody should be rich. And I think in this country you can be rich. If you devote ten years to one thing, you will be rich. I believe that. But the problem here is -- we talk about hypocrisy. In America, even a fool can have three homes but it's a problem when that fool doesn't want you to have three homes or is trying to get in the way of you wanting three homes. If Warren and Sanders were subjected to the plans that they want to subject to you, they would not be worth seven figures. They'd be worth maybe five figures and the decimal point would be here.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Can I just interrupt? There was a secret service agent that gave me some intel about Bernie's houses. They're disgusting messes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: He was on detail one time, went up to one of his places, and it was like an episode of hoarders, like just unopen mail, like food everywhere --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: That's my place.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Horrible.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: He might have three homes but they're all messes.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Are you surprised --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: No.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: But, Juan, this pulls well so we can't expect it to stop.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: What -- I mean, for Republicans?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: No, for Democrats to go after the billionaires. It pulls well.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Oh, absolutely. So, I mean, I think the key point here is that Democrats are representing their constituents. And I pick up on Jesse's point, Donald Trump is the richest of them all. And so, he says that he represents the forgotten man and the like, but he's the one who's out of touch. He's the one who said, oh, don't you have to have an I.D. to go into a grocery store? I'm sorry, Mr. President, no, you don't. He's the one who hired Wilbur Ross who told the federal workers when there was a shutdown, a Trump-caused shutdown, oh, you know what? Go to a bank and get a loan. Or how about Larry Kudlow, another Trumpian, right? What did Kudlow say? Oh, these guys who are forced to work for no pay, they're volunteering. They love --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: If he's so out of touch, Juan, why did he beat Hillary with middle-class voters?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: I'm telling you he's out of touch on things like the V.A., social security, Medicare, G.I. bill, livable wages --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Not with his --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: People who are dying in the V.A. wait lines under Barack Obama.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: All right, we've got to run. First it was Elizabeth Warren cracking a beer. Then we have Beto O'Rourke, remember that? The bizarre dentist appointment. But now another potential 2020 contender is getting roasted for a major social media fail. We'll show it to you next.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: It's another embarrassing social media blunder by a Democrat. After Elizabeth Warren tried to look cool cracking a beer, and Beto live streamed his dentist appointment, possible 2020 contender Eric Swalwell is being mobbed as a Starbucks martyr after trying to burn President Trump with this tweet, it's snowing in New York, I need coffee. The closest cafe is inside Trump Tower. This is me walking to an alternative. The congressman rightfully getting ripped on social media, after all this is New York City. As you can see, there's like over a dozen other coffee shops just within a few blocks, including a different Starbucks around the corner. Greg, not a smooth tweet, would you agree?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I go -- I say this all the time. The golden rule, you on twitter is a lesser version of you.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: And so --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Didn't have a lot to work with anyway.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yeah, he's already starting at a very low bar. But when you think in your head -- looks very cool, they going to -- and then you know that the media is going to pick it up and -- wait until they get a load of this idea. He's walking by -- I'm going to take a picture of me walking by Trump Tower and say, I'm not -- I'm going to be a hero. I'm not going in there. And so, what we see when we see the tweet is we see the thirst behind it.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: The desire. And then we go what a schmuck. That's why you've got to think about this before you do it. But social media has made us -- because exposure is more accessible now, everybody is turning into the star of their own movie, right? Everybody is doing this. We have Democratized the spotlight, Dana.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Well, I do feel like he should consider tea over coffee because it's very calming.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Oh, are you a tea proponent?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: I'm a tea proponent. Yeah, I don't drink coffee.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes, low tea.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Well, they can get tea at Starbucks too.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Yes. I also would advocate for -- if you're in New York, you should support the trucks, you know, the food trucks that are on the side of the road --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Sure.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: -- like, because those guys need your business.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Yeah. And Trump Tower needs your business too. Definitely could use that $1.25, right, Juan?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Why not. But I think Dana's wrong, by the way. I think there's more caffeine in tea than in coffee.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: No, there isn't. Juan, fake news.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Juan, have you ever stayed at a Trump Tower or any sort of Trump property? Do you think not staying there is cool?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Yes, I do. But I would not even go closer. I would run. You couldn't get the video of me because I'd be gone. So, I think, look, this is all levity. He thought he was having fun. Gee, on this show I hear all the time when Trump is on twitter, people say, ah, he's just -- you know, don't take it so seriously. Take it easy. OK, so have fun with this. But so -- I mean -- I guess if you want to just skewer him and say, oh, it's a Democrat, go right ahead. But, to me, it was like, you know what, all he was doing was indicated he doesn't like Trump. It's a free country.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Juan, look at all the dandruff on his --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Oh, is that dandruff?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: You know, I miss that.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: And we decide which jokes are funny, right? We don't let them get away with not funny jokes, right?

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.sentences: Yes. For me, it wasn't that he was a Democrat. It was that he was just one more thirsty person.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.sentences: Seeking that manufactured or he was manufacturing something that he wanted to be this viral video and you can see through it. That's the whole point.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: It doesn't matter who it is.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: It's about up the ante, right?

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: He's going off for beer, pretty soon it's going to be - somebody is going to smoke marijuana before this thing is through.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Tide Pods. Who do tide pods? Is that still in.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: No.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Do not listen to me. Do not listen to me.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: No tide pods.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Who is it going to be? Who is going to smoke pot before the end of this?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: No, but you've got to get some ...

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.sentences: I think it's crazy.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Calmness dad going after her.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: I know but you know what I feel bad for her.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Stereotyping Jamaicans.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Jamaicans.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: I feel bad for her for that.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: You really?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Because you don't want your dad to mind your own business.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: And you really shouldn't be stereotyping other cultures and ethnicities and nationalities. It's just it's below people. Chicago - what's so funny? Chicago's top cop blasting celebrities, the media and presidential candidates over the Jussie Smollett case.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Smollett.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: See you next.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Fox News alert, Actor Jussie Smollett charged with filing a false police report. Earlier today, the actor was blasted by Chicago's top police officer for lying about the alleged hate crime.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Empire actor Jussie Smollett took advantage of the pain and anger of racism to promote his career. I'm left hanging my head and asking why? Why would anyone especially an African-American man use the symbolism of a noose to make false accusations?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Mike Tobin is at Cook County Courthouse where Smollett had a bond hearing today. Mike, I asked that question yesterday.

utterances.speaker: EMILY COMPAGNO, HOST
utterances.utterance: Well, for the filing a false police report he could face as we've heard up to three years in prison and then a huge fine. And then for that letter, you know, there are consequences to the huge mechanism of responses that is put in place when you file a false police report and you allege a hate crime, or you send a letter with a threatening letter to a corporation building that then deploys a hazmat team, etcetera. So for that he could face up to ten years in prison. But I want to point out what I loved so much about the superintendent's comments --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Eddie Johnson, yeah.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.utterance: He brought it back to the real world, which is that there are real world consequences. And the hubris to me that emanates out of Hollywood where this celebrity will take something so painfully large such as the strife that has plague Chicago and this country in terms of its racial divide and historical consequences and symbolism of that news to shine for his own selfish gain because of a paycheck. That, to me is -- I just loved that the speech by the superintendent because I felt like he brought it home to the real world. He said this isn't TV. This is what happens.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Juan, he did -- he said -- or they claim it was because he was dissatisfied with his paycheck. Do you believe that?

utterances.speaker: JUAN WILLIAMS, HOST
utterances.utterance: I don't know what to believe. I mean, that's what the chief said.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: The chief said -- what were your thoughts on what he said?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Oh, I like the chief, you know, I mean -- and I think he was very clear that he's -- and part of his disappointment was that as a black man in seeing Smollett take advantage of the racial tensions in American society. But, again, it's all about him. It wasn't about anybody else but him. I will say this, when the chief said he'd like to see more attention paid to things like the shooting in Chicago, what else, or especially to the -- as much attention to the initial charge as to the finding that this young man lied about it. The chief's wrong. All the analysis shows that there's more attention now to the idea that he lied because it's a conspiracy issue. It's a fraud issue. It's celebrity gossip. There is more -- and don't forget, Donald Trump. Donald Trump has jumped in and said, you know, he was wrong, and it fits in with Donald Trump's attacks on the media, so all the Trump crowd is celebrating this in a way that I --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: No, they're just -- they're vindicated.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: No, they're not --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: They're vindicated.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Who said there was any need for them --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: They were accused. They were the symbolic accused.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: No, he said they put a red hat on one, but that wasn't the heart of the charge. And the letter was that he was the victim of some kind of racial crime. And again, there're so many racial crimes, we've seen a spike of racial crimes in the country --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: -- and he --this guy Smollett is so narcissistic that he is out of touch with reality. And the chief -- the chief should know more media attention, more cameras at that police department today than ever before.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Well, we can talk until the end of time about your misinterpretation of the facts. Let's go to GMA and get Smollett's own words before I get to Jesse.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.utterance: Why do you think you were targeted?

utterances.speaker: JUSSIE SMOLLETT, ACTOR
utterances.utterance: I can just assume, I mean, I come really, really hard against 45. I come really, really hard against his administration. And I don't hold my tongue. If I had said it was a Muslim or Mexican or someone black, I feel like the doubters would have supported me a lot much more.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: So, Jesse, when I listen to him, I see somebody who knew how to play the media because the media could be -- that's the language that the media understood if you're an activist media.

utterances.speaker: JESSE WATTERS, HOST
utterances.utterance: All right, he framed 60 million Trump supporters and the media bought it hook line and sinker. Juan, I think what the chief was saying also is that he'd like to see that much media attention when there's a shooting, or black on black violence, or gang activity in the south side of Chicago too. Now, Smollett makes reportedly from 400,000 to $1.1 million a year.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Sixty grand an episode, I believe.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: He does not have any children, which means he's filthy rich. So, instead of trying to earn more money working hard, he perpetrated this hoax. And everything he accused Donald Trump of, he himself is guilty of. He is a liar. He is corrupt. And he is greedy. So, just let that sink in also. Real hate crimes now are going to be treated with more skepticism, unfortunately, and that's what the police chief said, and I think that's probably one of the biggest results of this. Also, how dumb does Robin Roberts look right now when she went out there, didn't ask him any follow-up questions and let him perform like that? I bet she wish she had that back. Also, think about all the framed jobs and the conspiracy theories which we've seen. All it takes is a little common sense. You talked about it yesterday. There's a bunch of MAGA guys in a polar vortex in Chicago hate criming people. OK. Kavanaugh in high school, was he really participating in drug-fueled orgies? Or Covington, let's see -- wait a second, a 16-year-old, 115-pound kid was confronting some adult like the Ku Klux Klan? And now, Donald Trump, it makes you suspicious of the entire Russia investigation. He -- Donald Trump is a Russian asset? Donald Trump is a Russian asset? You don't have any sort of doubt when someone says that? If you don't believe that there is any sort of suspicion when someone says Trump is a Russian asset, you're crazy and you're going to fall for another one of these hoaxes.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: What about the U.S. landing on the moon? I think that calls -- this calls it into question.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Dana?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Oh, my gosh.

utterances.speaker: DANA PERINO, HOST
utterances.utterance: Well, a couple of things, one, so he makes $65,000 an episode. His bail was just set at $100,000. So he's going to post bail with a week and a half worth of work. I wonder how like the AOC's of the world feel about this filthy rich person being able to walk away free because -- you know, right, we need bail reform. The other thing though, I really like what Matt Lewis had to write today. I would cite him because I couldn't say it better. He writes for The Daily Beast. He said that the desire for sympathy and the moral authority that comes from being victimized has replaced the desire for admiration or respect for some act of heroism. So it's like victim chic. If you are a victim, then you're going to get more attention and he knew that. But I do think it's kind of bizarre though. To your point, he was able to fool some at the media, not all.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Remember, there were people on the left who are frustrated, like GQ Magazine wrote about the reporter in this case saying how dare they use the word, allegedly.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: That that was whitewashing the idea that this was a hate crime when reporters were just actually doing their job.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: By the way, Jesse, I think with the Robin Roberts thing, we use the tape of the interview. I think that is an indication that she actually got this guy to say what he wanted to say. And for him, that's part of the indictment of him.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: That's true. He set himself up.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: That's what I'm saying So I don't think that's the reporter.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Well, I would have asked a few more follow-ups, that's all I'm saying. No offense to Robin --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: You would have quiz her on geography and -- anyway. All right, much more on Smollett -- Smollett, ahead. But first, major hypocrisy from 2020 Dems pushing socialist agendas, details next. Peter Tork.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Welcome back, 2020 Democratic contenders are being accused of hypocrisy for publicly slamming the rich while privately rolling in the dough. Watch this.

utterances.speaker: SEN. BERNIE SANDERS, I-VT
utterances.utterance: We should not have a grotesque level of wealth inequality in which three billionaires now own more wealth than the bottom half of the country.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.utterance: We have a tax bill that got past that gave a trillion dollars to the top 1 percent and the biggest corporations of America. And they need to give that money back.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.utterance: I want these billionaires to stop being freeloaders. I want them to pick up their fair share.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Some are calling foul on those candidates for these reasons. First, Bernie Sanders owned three houses and has earned over a million bucks in recent years. Kamala Harris reportedly held a fund-raiser in Beverly Hills attended by wealthy Hollywood and TV executives. And Elizabeth Warren's net worth is reportedly more than $8 million putting her in the top 1 percent, indeed. On -- one of the staffers twitter profiles for Congresswoman Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez, it says every -- for every billionaire is a policy mistake. Jesse, so now it's gone from trying to help bring the bottom up by, like, incentives or education, but now it's just completely top-down.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I wonder if she thinks George Soros is a mistake. Tell that to his face, AOC. I don't think they're even that rich anyway. I mean, $1 million, I mean, compared to Donald Trump or some of these other people, that's nothing. Remember what Trump said about --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: That's their point.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: What Trump said about Mitt Romney. He's poor.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: And he walks like a penguin. When I see a wealthy person with a yacht, I don't get jealous. I get competitive and I want to own my own yacht. I want to work for my yacht. And I don't want to take that yacht away from someone else. I want to get it myself. And I think that's what the Democrats are kind of off. They see wealthy people and they want to make them less wealthy. I think they should be looking at poor people and say how do you make poor people less poor? Look what Barack Obama did. Barack Obama raised taxes on the rich. Middle-class wages didn't grow. The deficit didn't get paid down. Manufacturing jobs weren't created and the poverty rate stayed the same. So I don't see a big economic success when you raised taxes on the rich. I think they just waste the money on pork and corruption.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: When you are -- in Seattle. You live in Seattle. And so, there's a lot of tension between, sort of, more the local folks there that are mad about the tech companies and the billionaires and it's created a lot of tension there. And wasn't it just recently that they tried to raise taxes and then they had to backtrack because businesses were going to leave?

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.utterance: It was a huge deal. And then, Amazon donated $500 million to combat homelessness. So there's also a dependency on the private funding that happens in addition to what it does for the industry there, absolutely. I think my biggest issue with all of this is the hypocrisy knows no bounds for these politicians. Like for example, you know, Elizabeth Warren, you know, she has -- she's millions in her funds and that include -- those funds include gun manufacturers and big tobacco and all of the things that she rails against. And it's that same hypocrisy that we hear up and down where people -- you know, walk the walk. Don't just talk the talk. We have Bernie Sanders, the day that his campaign paid $300,000 in jet airplane costs for his campaign, he tweeted out that climate change was a planetary crisis. So it's --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I see, yeah.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.utterance: -- it's everything.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: There is -- a coin a phrase, selective billionaire outrage.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: SBO.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: SBO. They like --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: SBO.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: They don't like billionaires.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: He's got SBO, which stinks.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: We'll be right back.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: What do you think of that, SBO?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: You can treat it with super beats.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Because they have like Tom Steyer.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yeah, you know -- OK, OK. So I'm -- Bernie has three houses which prove a point that you can be a successful socialist if you act like a capitalist. That's the only way it's going to work. I'm not going to bash these -- any of these people for being wealthy because I think it's great that they're wealthy. I think everybody should be rich. And I think in this country you can be rich. If you devote ten years to one thing, you will be rich. I believe that. But the problem here is -- we talk about hypocrisy. In America, even a fool can have three homes but it's a problem when that fool doesn't want you to have three homes or is trying to get in the way of you wanting three homes. If Warren and Sanders were subjected to the plans that they want to subject to you, they would not be worth seven figures. They'd be worth maybe five figures and the decimal point would be here.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Can I just interrupt? There was a secret service agent that gave me some intel about Bernie's houses. They're disgusting messes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: He was on detail one time, went up to one of his places, and it was like an episode of hoarders, like just unopen mail, like food everywhere --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: That's my place.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Horrible.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: He might have three homes but they're all messes.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Are you surprised --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: No.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: But, Juan, this pulls well so we can't expect it to stop.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: What -- I mean, for Republicans?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: No, for Democrats to go after the billionaires. It pulls well.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Oh, absolutely. So, I mean, I think the key point here is that Democrats are representing their constituents. And I pick up on Jesse's point, Donald Trump is the richest of them all. And so, he says that he represents the forgotten man and the like, but he's the one who's out of touch. He's the one who said, oh, don't you have to have an I.D. to go into a grocery store? I'm sorry, Mr. President, no, you don't. He's the one who hired Wilbur Ross who told the federal workers when there was a shutdown, a Trump-caused shutdown, oh, you know what? Go to a bank and get a loan. Or how about Larry Kudlow, another Trumpian, right? What did Kudlow say? Oh, these guys who are forced to work for no pay, they're volunteering. They love --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: If he's so out of touch, Juan, why did he beat Hillary with middle-class voters?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I'm telling you he's out of touch on things like the V.A., social security, Medicare, G.I. bill, livable wages --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Not with his --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: People who are dying in the V.A. wait lines under Barack Obama.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: All right, we've got to run. First it was Elizabeth Warren cracking a beer. Then we have Beto O'Rourke, remember that? The bizarre dentist appointment. But now another potential 2020 contender is getting roasted for a major social media fail. We'll show it to you next.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: It's another embarrassing social media blunder by a Democrat. After Elizabeth Warren tried to look cool cracking a beer, and Beto live streamed his dentist appointment, possible 2020 contender Eric Swalwell is being mobbed as a Starbucks martyr after trying to burn President Trump with this tweet, it's snowing in New York, I need coffee. The closest cafe is inside Trump Tower. This is me walking to an alternative. The congressman rightfully getting ripped on social media, after all this is New York City. As you can see, there's like over a dozen other coffee shops just within a few blocks, including a different Starbucks around the corner. Greg, not a smooth tweet, would you agree?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I go -- I say this all the time. The golden rule, you on twitter is a lesser version of you.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: And so --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Didn't have a lot to work with anyway.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yeah, he's already starting at a very low bar. But when you think in your head -- looks very cool, they going to -- and then you know that the media is going to pick it up and -- wait until they get a load of this idea. He's walking by -- I'm going to take a picture of me walking by Trump Tower and say, I'm not -- I'm going to be a hero. I'm not going in there. And so, what we see when we see the tweet is we see the thirst behind it.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: The desire. And then we go what a schmuck. That's why you've got to think about this before you do it. But social media has made us -- because exposure is more accessible now, everybody is turning into the star of their own movie, right? Everybody is doing this. We have Democratized the spotlight, Dana.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Well, I do feel like he should consider tea over coffee because it's very calming.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Oh, are you a tea proponent?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I'm a tea proponent. Yeah, I don't drink coffee.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes, low tea.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Well, they can get tea at Starbucks too.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Yes. I also would advocate for -- if you're in New York, you should support the trucks, you know, the food trucks that are on the side of the road --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Sure.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: -- like, because those guys need your business.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yeah. And Trump Tower needs your business too. Definitely could use that $1.25, right, Juan?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Why not. But I think Dana's wrong, by the way. I think there's more caffeine in tea than in coffee.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: No, there isn't. Juan, fake news.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Juan, have you ever stayed at a Trump Tower or any sort of Trump property? Do you think not staying there is cool?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes, I do. But I would not even go closer. I would run. You couldn't get the video of me because I'd be gone. So, I think, look, this is all levity. He thought he was having fun. Gee, on this show I hear all the time when Trump is on twitter, people say, ah, he's just -- you know, don't take it so seriously. Take it easy. OK, so have fun with this. But so -- I mean -- I guess if you want to just skewer him and say, oh, it's a Democrat, go right ahead. But, to me, it was like, you know what, all he was doing was indicated he doesn't like Trump. It's a free country.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Juan, look at all the dandruff on his --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Oh, is that dandruff?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: You know, I miss that.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: And we decide which jokes are funny, right? We don't let them get away with not funny jokes, right?

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.utterance: Yes. For me, it wasn't that he was a Democrat. It was that he was just one more thirsty person.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.utterance: Seeking that manufactured or he was manufacturing something that he wanted to be this viral video and you can see through it. That's the whole point.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: It doesn't matter who it is.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: It's about up the ante, right?

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: He's going off for beer, pretty soon it's going to be - somebody is going to smoke marijuana before this thing is through.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Tide Pods. Who do tide pods? Is that still in.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: No.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Do not listen to me. Do not listen to me.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: No tide pods.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Who is it going to be? Who is going to smoke pot before the end of this?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: No, but you've got to get some ...

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.utterance: I think it's crazy.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Calmness dad going after her.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I know but you know what I feel bad for her.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Stereotyping Jamaicans.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Jamaicans.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I feel bad for her for that.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: You really?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Because you don't want your dad to mind your own business.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: And you really shouldn't be stereotyping other cultures and ethnicities and nationalities. It's just it's below people. Chicago - what's so funny? Chicago's top cop blasting celebrities, the media and presidential candidates over the Jussie Smollett case.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Smollett.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: See you next.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Fox News alert, Actor Jussie Smollett charged with filing a false police report. Earlier today, the actor was blasted by Chicago's top police officer for lying about the alleged hate crime.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: Empire actor Jussie Smollett took advantage of the pain and anger of racism to promote his career. I'm left hanging my head and asking why? Why would anyone especially an African-American man use the symbolism of a noose to make false accusations?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Mike Tobin is at Cook County Courthouse where Smollett had a bond hearing today. Mike, I asked that question yesterday.

utterances.speaker: MIKE TOBIN, REPORTER
utterances.utterance: Well, I can tell you this one that Smollett is now out. He posted $10,000 and left under a tremendous crush of media. Some of what you didn't catch with all the live coverage today is that the judge John Lyke admonished Smollett in the courtroom saying If true, what he did was utterly outrageous and he conjured up the greatest evil in our nation, specifically referring to the racist symbolism that he brought into the hoax attack. Some of what we learned today that we didn't already knew, while we knew the Smollett was associates with the Osundairo brothers, one of them was a source from whom he would buy the party drug, Molly. We did know that he directed the attack, but he specifically directed the brothers to beat him up, but not too bad. And we've got hints that he intended - from the ABC interview that he intended for the attack to play out in front of a security camera that didn't catch it and his awareness with the attack. We learned from the state's attorney is part of what tipped investigators off to something being fishy. The whole thing went down in 45 seconds. The motive was pay. Smollett didn't think he was getting enough or got enough attention from the threatening letter that went to the Empire studio, so he upped the ante with the attack. Bond is set at $100,000. He posted $10,000. His status with the show is unchanged. His attorney said, he was scheduled to shoot this afternoon. The people followed his SUV said, it went into the Cinespace Studios, where Empire is shot. Juan.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Mike, thanks. Good job. The Chicago police superintendent also calling out celebrities, politicians and the media for rushing to judgment.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: This publicity stunt was a scar that Chicago didn't earn and certainly didn't deserve. To make things worse, the accusations within this phony attack received national attention for weeks. Celebrities, news commentators and even presidential candidates weighed in on something that was choreographed by an actor. I only hope that the truth about what happened receives the same amount of attention that the hoax did. I'll continue to pray for this troubled young man who resorted to both drastic and illegal tactics to gain attention.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I mean it really is pretty horrific if it's true that this guy made this up. As I said to you earlier Greg, you know the major networks and the cable news outlets have all paid more attention to this case after the charge that it's a hoax.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Well, the thing is I mean I can't believe I'm going to say this, but I do believe that he is kind of a victim because of the environment. This is entirely preventable. This could have been prevented if the media divorced itself from its activist sensibilities. They are - since Trump has been elected, they've been informed by an anti-Trump bias that makes this kind of activity plausible. He knew he could fool the media. I also think that he had his own Trump derangement syndrome just as Kathy Griffin, as Tom Arnold and Alyssa Milano.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: So, this is all about Trump?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: No. No, I was talking about the media. Let me--

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: You said, media is obsessed with Trump dislike and that's why they went--

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: But I'm saying to you that in fact the media is paying more attention to it now that it's--

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: After they waited three weeks, because they were terrified of saying anything.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Charged that it's a fraud.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Look, I'm going to go. I want to make a suggestion that I listen to Scott Adams today that what Donald Trump could do is actually suggest that this guy gets pardoned by the governor, because he knows he is the victim of Trump derangement syndrome and that actually invite him to the White House and have a summit and help this kid out, because clearly he's mentally unstable due to his Trump derangement. I think that's brilliant.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Brilliant.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
